intro: Capraria biflora var. pilosa, commonly known as the hairy capraria, is a flowering plant native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of water bodies, thriving in moist, sandy soils. Its foliage is often covered in fine, woolly hairs, which give it a distinctive appearance. The species is part of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton plants.
